sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many with mental illness do not seek treatment, often due to stigma; be it public, self, or institutional type. To improve outcomes, stigma needs addressing.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Understand the opportunity for e-mental health to help overcome stigma and, to provide an expert opinion to foster its adoption.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We conducted literature searches using the terms ((mental health) AND ((stigma) OR (discrimination))) AND (((((digital tools) OR (digital services)) OR (healthcare apps)) OR (digital solutions)) OR (digital technology)), limited to 2007 – 2023, identifying 223 citations, 9 of which were relevant for this evaluation, including 4 systematic reviews ( Table 1).

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Literature reports suggest that e-mental health may be useful for addressing stigma and reducing the treatment gap. While it was not consistently as good as face-to-face services, e-mental health tools were frequently shown to be effective in reducing stigma, improving mental health literacy, and increasing help-seeking behaviors. Tools included web-based breathing, meditation, and CBT; suicide prevention apps; and online videos and games. Experts from a 2022 global Think Tank session convened by eMHIC, opined and emphasised that embracing e-mental health must not leave people behind nor reinforce inequality and that structural barriers must first be acknowledged and overcome. Creating a shared understanding of the challenge and of terminology is essential, as is codesigning any solution together with people with lived experience. Table 1.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Published data suggest that e-mental health is promising to reduce stigma and discrimination, with the potential to foster help-seeking and treatment engagement. Adoption requires attention to derailers and must foster inclusivity. There is an imperative to adopt e-mental health, especially evidence-based solutions.
